response.answer_text: What is average density? Short answer: The average density (symbol ρ (rho)) [math]=[/math] mass divided by volume, which says nothing about any “density distribution” within the volume. Say e.g., we have a one kg (1 000 g) mass in one cubic decimeter, made up of 1 000 cm[math]^3[/math] cubes of varying mass — some [math]>[/math] 1 g, some [math]<[/math] 1 g, and some [math]=[/math] 1 g mass. The average density of the box [math]=[/math] 1 000 (g) / 1 000 (cm[math]^3[/math]) [math]=[/math] 1 g/cm[math]^3[/math], just as if it was a homogeneous block of a substance of that density. Wikipedia article Density says: The density, or more precisely, the volumetric mass density, of a substance is its mass per unit volume, The symbol most often used for density is ρ (the lower case Greek letter rho), although the Latin letter D can also be used. Mathematically, density is defined as mass divided by volume: [math]{\displaystyle \rho ={\frac {m}{V}},}[/math] where ρ is the density, m is the mass, and V is the volume. In some cases (for instance, in the United States oil and gas industry), density is loosely defined as its weight per unit volume, although this is scientifically inaccurate — this quantity is more specifically called specific weight. Picky, picky … One extreme “average density” is that of the whole Universe — if we accept published scientific estimates[math]^{[1]}[/math] of total mass ([math]\approx[/math] 10[math]^{53}[/math]kg) and volume (4[math]×[/math]10[math]^{80}[/math]m[math]^3[/math]), the term “average density” takes on a whole new meaning: Average Universe density ρ[math]_{Univ}[/math] [math]≈[/math] 10[math]^{53}[/math]/4[math]×[/math]10[math]^{80}≈[/math] 2.5[math]×[/math]10[math]^{-28}[/math]kg/m[math]^3[/math]. This “average density” is a much better vacuum than any ever — actually, impossible to ever be — produced in Earth based scientific labs! The theoretical “unified atomic mass” (unit u (or Da), roughly the mass of one proton) is 1.6605[math]×[/math]10[math]^{-27}[/math]kg . Calculating a rough total number of protons in the Universe, 10[math]^{53}[/math]kg/1.6605[math]×[/math]10[math]^{-27}[/math]kg [math]≈[/math] 6×10[math]^{79}[/math], “pretty close” to the often cited value 10[math]^{80}[/math] (one estimate of N[math]_{Edd}[/math], Eddington’s number).[math]^{[2]}[/math] This means that the “average particle density” of the “observable Universe” is a mind-bogglingly dilute 6[math]×[/math]10[math]^{79}[/math]/4[math]×[/math]10[math]^{80}[/math]m[math]^3≈[/math] 1.67 protons per cubic meter!  Disclaimer: My results (based on Wikipedia inputs) deviate considerably from those published in Wikipedia … One of us is wrong, but I don’t know what kind of math the Wikipedia scientists used (I notice that the author figured the Universe volume based on a Universe radius [math]≈[/math] 46.5 Gly, which would explain some of the density discrepancies (e.g., it is clear that the NASA/WMAP cosmologists (astrophysicists?) have used a Universe radius [math]≈[/math] 13.8 Gly)[math]^{[4]}[/math] — I have double-checked my own numbers, but cannot see my error(s) … If someone could find them — and correct me — would be Great! Footnotes [1] Universe mass and volume source: Wikipedia, Observable Universe. The volume cited — 4[math]×[/math]10[math]^{80}[/math]m[math]^3[/math]— tells me that they have used a Universe radius of around 46.5 billion lightyears. [2] Fun scientific trivia: According to Wikipedia, Eddington once claimed (in a lecture, presumably tongue-in-cheek): I believe there are 15 747 724 136 275 002 577 605 653 961 181 555 468 044 717 914 527 116 709 366 231 425 076 185 631 031 296 protons in the universe and the same number of electrons. The value 10[math]^{80}[/math]is more than six times larger … [3] I find it interesting that the “critical” Universe density — which in theory tells us if the Universe “curvature” is negative, “flat” (i.e., critical density = actual density), or positive — can be calculated based only on the “Hubble parameter,” current “best value” H[math]_0[/math]= 70 km/s/Mpc and Newton’s constant! The formula is ρ[math]_{Crit}[/math] [math]=[/math] 3H[math]_0^2[/math]/(8πG), and if we plug in the numbers we get ρ[math]_{Crit}[/math] [math]≈[/math] 9.2042[math]×[/math]10[math]^{-27}[/math] kg/m[math]^3[/math] — so in this crude calculation, the estimated Universe density is about 37 times lower than the critical density, which would mean that the Universe curvature is negative (whatever that might mean to the price of rice in China) — something is off here … [4] The map.gsfc.nasa.gov page Content of the Universe publishes yet another set of numbers (dates all the way back to January 2013, in “modern precision cosmology” terms, extremely outdated, but still): WMAP determined that the universe is flat, from which it follows that the mean energy density in the universe is equal to the critical density (within a 0.5% margin of error). This is equivalent to a mass density of 9.9[math]×[/math]10[math]^{-27}[/math] kg/m[math]^3[/math], which is equivalent to only 5.9 protons per cubic meter. According to these numbers, the NASA/WMAP scientists live in a Universe where its radius (13.8 Gly) corresponds to its age (13.8 Gy).

The total weight of a system divided by its total volume. Eg. A system with a wooden block with iron nails in it has an average density somewhere between wood and iron. If you know the densities of both materials the average density is (w1d1+w2d2+w3d3+…)/(w1+w2+w3+..) where wi is weight of the component and di is density of the material of said component.
